articles.title: Australia needs to be part of a ‘global effort' to reduce emissions to ‘limit global warming'
articles.summary: Climate Change Authority chair Matt Kean claims climate change is having a 'catastrophic impact' on the world and Australia needs to be part of a 'global effort' to reduce emissions. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced Australia's 2035 climate target on Thursday following a federal cabinet meeting.

articles.title: Experts issue warning that huge number of homes could soon become uninsurable: 'There is no doubt'
articles.author: Robert English
articles.summary: There are 380,000 homes in Australia that are uninsurable or too expensive to insure. By 2035, this figure could increase to one in every 10 homes. Average home insurance premiums have risen by 66% in the Greater Sydney area since 2020. According to Australia's first National Climate Risk Assessment, every community in the country is affected by the changing climate. Home insurance protects property owners from the burden of paying for damages and fixes. California may provide a roadmap for tackling this issue.

articles.title: Today's News Headlines: Armed man arrested at Charlie Kirk's memorial
articles.summary: Donald Trump rolls out $1.5 million 'Gold Card' visa. US Republicans send Anthony Albanese an open letter over Australia's Palestine stance. Tony Abbott warns of climate target effects and Donald Trump warns of the effects of climate change on the US economy.

articles.title: Australia's looming landfill crisis is fixable but ...
articles.author: Abe Maddison
articles.summary: The volume of waste generated by Australia will soon be beyond its capacity to deal with, as it will soon also be beyond the capacity of the country's resources to cope with it. It is too vast to comprehend. It will be too much for Australia to handle.

articles.title: Hotter summers in Virginia mean higher power bills. What can be done about it?
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Some areas of Hampton Roads struggle with unaffordable energy bills more than others. A warming climate means longer and hotter summers in Hampton Roads, which means higher energy bills for some people. Especially for renters, there's an even higher energy burden there, according to the Virginia Poverty Law.

articles.title: Scientists Detect Mysterious Gravity Shift Near Earth's Core
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: The change occurred between 2006 and 2008. It was detected using data from a pair of US-German satellites that once measured variations in Earth's gravity. Researchers believe the shift may have been triggered when the structure of rocks near the boundary between Earth's core and mantle transformed, becoming denser.

articles.title: Coalition denial makes Labor seem reasonable on climate – but neither is ambitious enough
articles.author: Zoe Daniel
articles.summary: Only an ambitious government can reap the economic benefits of the net zero transition for the Australian people. Labor is setting a target range in line with its usual pragmatic caution. The opposition leader, Sussan Ley, touted the Coalition's economic credentials in a recent speech. Deloitte modelling suggests a 75% emissions reduction target by 2035 versus 65% could yield $227bn in additional GDP over 10 years.

articles.title: George Russell: Sausalito finds itself surrounded by sea-level rise
articles.author: Marin Independent Journal
articles.summary: Sausalito faces problems because of rising bay waters, city consultants said during a forum on neighborhood options for adapting to rising sea levels by 2050 and 2100, according to the forum on adapting to Rising Sea Levels by 2050-2100.    .

articles.title: Climate resilience is key to peacebuilding in Somalia

articles.title: Iberian heatwaves 200 times more likely
articles.author: Tpn Lusa
articles.summary: Climate change has increased the likelihood of wildfires in Portugal and Spain by 40 times. Heat waves are 200 times more likely and about 3°C more intense. The burned area in the Iberian Peninsula represents about two-thirds of Europe's total area. The researchers recommend structured preventive measures and local land management.

articles.title: City council 'doing all we can' to prepare for worse flooding, says Lord Mayor

articles.summary: Climate change is already having an impact on storms and flooding in Wollongong. The Hewitts Creek floodplain risk management study and plan, covering Thirroul and Bulli, includes a 0.3m rise in flood levels by 2025 in its calculations. It's on exhibition for public comment until September 26. The council's flood risk plans already include projections of increased rainfall due to climate change.

articles.summary: The Great Replacement is a far-right conspiracy theory that posits elites are conspiring to replace America's white, Christian populations with nonwhite immigrants. articles.title: Future Directions in Flood Risk and Climate Change
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of flooding events. Flooding poses a significant threat to communities, infrastructure, and ecosystems. Low-lying areas, such as coastal cities and river deltas, are particularly vulnerable due to their geographical characteristics. Poverty, population density, and inadequate infrastructure can amplify the impacts of flooding on communities. Technology can improve flood forecasting and early warning systems.

articles.title: Brace for a blizzard of calls for needlessly painful measures as Climate Week takes over NYC
articles.author: Post Editorial Board
articles.summary: Starting Sunday, Climate Week NYC will blare propaganda aiming to 'drive the transition,' shift 'entire systems' and 'speed up progress' toward 'changing climate'. The event will use fear to push draconian measures that'll slow the economy and sow widespread misery. Climate change is real and worthy of concern, but the alarmists' worries are woefully overblown and their plans far more costly than the possible benefits.

articles.title: Researchers look for meaning in NH's shrinking snowpack
articles.author: Alex Veiga
articles.summary: The average amount of snow that accumulates on the ground throughout the winter season, or snowpack, is shrinking from year to year across the Northeast. Researchers working in the forests of New Hampshire and the Northeast are learning more about how far the phenomenon stretches across seasons and landscapes.

articles.title: Haiti - Environment : «When Haiti acts on climate challenges, it builds a safer future» - HaitiLibre.com : Haiti news 7/7

UNDP Haiti supported the Ministry of the Environment in organizing a national workshop aimed at strengthening institutional capacity. Consultants Vovener de Verlin and Raoul Vital put the political and sectoral challenges of the NDC into perspective. They recommended strengthening the legal framework, integrating seismic and climate standards into the building code, and implementing risk zoning.

articles.title: The dirty, rotten deal at the heart of Higgins v Reynolds: Yes, her tweets were foolish lies - but everyone in Canberra knows how this all REALLY started. I'm finally going to say it: PVO

articles.author: Staff Writer
articles.summary: The RSPCA Isle of Wight is inviting residents to take part in a Fire Walk Challenge this autumn. The event takes place on Saturday 8th November 2025 at Havenstreet Station from 4pm to 7pm. Participants will walk across glowing embers to raise funds that will provide shelter, veterinary care and a second chance for animals on the Island.

articles.title: Revealed: The 5 foods you should NEVER cook straight from the freezer
articles.author: SHIVALI BEST
articles.summary: Experts from Which? have revealed the five foods you should never cook without carefully defrosting. Raw chicken should never be cooked from frozen as it can lead to uneven cooking and bacteria growth. Home-frozen sasauges always need to be fully defrosted before cooking. Mince is dense and should be thawed first.

articles.title: Data gaps hinder country's case for climate aid
articles.summary: In the absence of reliable climate data, Bangladesh's development is hampering national progress and adaptation efforts. The data deficit extends across multiple sectors, creating a cascade of development challenges. Lack of reliable data prevents evidence-based policymaking, international funding access, and effective adaptation planning.

articles.title: Atmospheric hydrogen is rising, which may be a problem for the climate
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Ice core records of atmospheric hydrogen reveal a huge rise in concentration since the Industrial Revolution. This has contributed to global warming and could sway the debate over hydrogen as a fuel, as it could affect the debate on whether it's still a good fuel for humans.

articles.title: Fall foliage to be more ‘vibrant,' last longer this year in Ontario
articles.author: Caryn Lieberman
articles.summary: The fall foliage is arriving earlier than usual this year because of the dry weather and heat. articles.title: Unveiling Earth's Secret: Core-Mantle Boundary Shift Discovered
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Scientists have identified a rare geological shift at the boundary between Earth's core and mantle. This transformation occurred between 2006 and 2008. The discovery was made using data from the Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment (GRACE), a US-German satellite mission operational from 2002 to 2017. Perovskite, a mineral found in rocks deep within the mantle, altered structurally under immense pressure, increasing rock density. The resultant shift possibly deformed the core-mantle boundary by about 10 centimeters.

articles.title: Sun and Cosmic Rays Drive Climate, Not CO2, Says Astrophysicist
articles.author: The Daily Sceptic
articles.summary: Danish astrophysicist Dr Henrik Svensmark says it's a bad career move to go against the idea that CO2 is the only driver of climate change. For many it means losing research funding for many scientists. "Climate science is not normal science".

articles.title: Letter: When ‘consensus' looks more like ‘unsettled'
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Greg Bradburn and Jorge Smirnoff both miss the forest for the trees in their recent letters. Bradburn claims the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) can't affect global sea surface temperatures because it simply 'shuffles heat around'. That's like insisting your thermostat can't change your home's average temperature because it's only present in one room.

articles.title: Letter: When ‘consensus' looks more like ‘unsettled'
articles.author: Letters to the Editor
articles.summary: Greg Bradburn and Jorge Smirnoff are wrong about the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO) and global sea surface temperatures. The Pacific Ocean covers a third of the planet and shifts between storing heat in the deep and releasing it to the surface, the global average moves.

articles.summary: Deforestation-induced warming linked to 28,000 deaths a year. South and Central America has the greatest deforestation in the tropics, with an area the size of Turkey lost.

articles.summary: The catalpa tree leaves are fading yellow. The seasons are changing. The recent temperatures reached into the mid-90's, but it might not feel like it, but the times and the times are changing and so are the seasons.

articles.title: Understanding UK Time: A Guide to Time Zones and Changes
articles.author: Coin Fellowship
articles.summary: The United Kingdom operates under Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) during the winter months and British Summer Time (BST) during summer months. This regular progression of time aids in scheduling and connects the UK with global time coordination. The UK is primarily dialled in the Eastern Time Zone.

articles.summary: In 2007, the Legislature passed a law requiring areas with 200 floodplains to have levees that could withstand flooding events. articles.title: Arabian Sea creeps inland, drowning sugar heartland of Pakistan's Sindh
articles.author: Ismail Dilawar
articles.summary: Sea intrusion and shrinking freshwater flows from the Indus River have left the soil too saline for sugarcane in Badin district, Pakistan's second-largest province. Farmers are shifting to climate-resilient crops such as rice and wheat. The district used to produce 30% of Pakistan's national sugar output. Mirza Sugar Mill and Pangrio Sugar Mills shut down.

articles.title: FIRE IN THE FOREST: Why bush burning never goes away
articles.author: Theopeyemi A.A²
articles.summary: Bush burning is a common practice in rural Nigeria despite warnings of its dangers. It destroys crops, kills livestock, displaces families and pollutes the environment. articles.author: David Wafula

Locals described loss of lives, destruction of farms, and permanent injuries caused by lions, buffaloes, snakes, sharks, stingrays and other dangerous animals.

articles.title: Monsoon Season 2025 Officially Ended: PDMA Shared Updates and Losses Report!
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: The monsoon season in Punjab has officially ended. There is no forecast of further rain in the coming week. The floods have affected 4,755 villages across 28 districts. 123 deaths have been confirmed. More than 4.5 million people have been impacted. Alipur, Multan, and Jalalpur were among the worst hit. 2.482 million acres of agricultural land were affected.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg monitored by China's Fengyun satellites
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: A23a, the world's largest iceberg, has lost about 60 percent of its size since early 2025. Scientists warn that the continued melting of A23a underscores the rapid pace of climate change and its impact on global sea levels. China's Fengyun-3 weather satellites have been monitoring the disintegration of the iceberg.

articles.title: Researchers issue warning after discovering concerning phenomenon across US and Canada: 'We need to start preparing'
articles.author: Amy Boyington
articles.summary: Glaciers across the western United States, Canada, and Switzerland are melting faster than ever. American and Canadian glaciers lost about 12% of their ice volume since 2020. Swiss glaciers saw even more of a loss, at 13%. The researchers linked the rapid melt to unusually warm and dry conditions and early-season heat waves.

articles.title: Climate Change & You: Is India's deadly air pollution saving us from the worst effects of global warming?
articles.author: Bibek Bhattacharya
articles.summary: Bibek Bhattacharya and Sayantan Bera are sending their fortnightly Climate Change & You newsletter to their readers. In this newsletter, Bibek and Bera discuss the link between climate change and atmospheric pollution. Professor AchutaRao, from the Centre for Atmospheric Sciences, IIT (Delhi), explains that there is a clear connection between rising heat and pollution. Fossil fuel companies are causing more heatwaves.

articles.title: Widow's £1 Million Clifftop Home Faces Demolition Due to Coastal Erosion
articles.author: Daily Mail UK
articles.summary: Jean Flick's home in Thorpeness, Suffolk, is threatened by coastal erosion. She has lived there for 25 years and hopes to stay there as long as possible. The situation highlights the impact of climate change on coastal communities and the need for coastal management solutions.

articles.title: Regional report highlights challenges to human development
articles.author: Cubanew Acn
articles.summary: The UNDP has published the 2025 Regional Human Development Report on the Latin America and the Caribbean. The report highlights the vulnerability of Cuba and the rest of the Caribbean to the impacts of climate change and demographic transition. Cuba's Human Development Index is above 0.7 points, but it is still far behind the countries with very high human development.
